details.title: Unbiased Variance Estimates for System Reliability Estimate Using Block Decompositions

p: Tongdan Jin (M'06) is an Assistant Professor at Texas A&M International University (TAMIU). Prior to TAMIU, he worked for five years as a Reliability Engineer at Teradyne Inc., Boston. He holds a Ph.D. from industrial engineering and MS in electrical and computer engineering, both from Rutgers University in 2001. His recent publications appeared in IEEE Transactions on Reliability, IIE Transactions, and Reliability Engineering and System Safety. His research interests include reliability estimations, modeling, and optimization for complex systems.

David W. Coit (M'03) is an Associate Professor in the Department of Industrial & Systems Engineering at Rutgers University. He received a BS degree in mechanical engineering from Cornell University, an MBA from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, and MS & Ph.D. in industrial engineering from the University of Pittsburgh. In 1999, he was awarded a CAREER grant from NSF to study reliability optimization. He also has over ten years of experience working for IIT Research Institute (IITRI), Rome, NY, where he was a reliability analyst, project manager, and an engineering group manager. His current research involves reliability prediction & optimization, risk analysis, and multi-criteria optimization considering uncertainty. He is a member of IIE and INFORMS.

details.abstract: An unbiased estimator is proposed to calculate the variance of a system reliability estimate based on the estimated variance of component reliability estimates. The method does not require any parametric assumptions for component reliability or time-to-failure, and it allows Type-I and Type-II censored data. The approach can be applied to many situations as long as the system can be appropriately decomposed into series or parallel configurations. The new model is compared with existing methods using different reliability data and system structures. The empirical results show that the new model is generally superior in terms of computational efficiency, and estimation accuracy.

references.title: An improved confidence bounds for system reliability

context.text: Recursive decomposition can be used to provide an unbiased estimate of the variance [1].

Ramirez-Marquez & Jiang [1] developed a recursive model based on Goodman's results to estimate the variance of reliability estimates for systems that can be transformed into equivalent series-parallel systems.
The unbiased estimate presented by Ramirez-Marquez & Jiang [1] is a special case for (17) when only two components are connected in series.
In the next section, two examples are presented to demonstrate the proposed method, and the results are compared to the data given by [1], [2].
The method proposed by Ramirez-Marquez & Jiang [1] belongs to USUC, yet it is based on recursive iterations.
The second example was originally presented by Ramirez-Marquez & Jiang [1] based on the same system structure in Fig. 4.
Simulations are also applied to the data set given in Table III from [1].
Furthermore, it is recommended that a USUC metric be used, either the recursive relationship proposed by Ramirez-Marquez & Jiang [1] or the analytical methods proposed in this paper.

links.abstract: In this paper, new bounding strategies are presented to improve confidence interval estimation for system reliability based on component level reliability, and associated uncertainty data. Research efforts have been focused on two interdependent areas: 1) development & improvement of analytical approaches for quantifying the uncertainty associated with the system reliability estimate when data regarding component reliability is available; and 2) based on these analytical approaches, generating s...

references.text: J. E. Ramirez-Marquez, W. Jiang, "An improved confidence bounds for system reliability", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 55, no. 1, pp. 26-36, 2006.

references.title:
System reliability confidence intervals
for complex systems with estimated component reliability

context.text: One of the first papers to relate component reliability estimate variance to the system-level was published by Coit [2], who presented models to approximate the variance based on a system variance decomposition method.
This estimate has been presented by Coit [2].
Reference [2] also derived (23) for parallel systems.

For a series-parallel system with \$s\$ subsystems, and each subsystem has \$m_{i}\$ components (for \$i=1,2,\ldots,s\$) connected in parallel, the variance of the system reliability estimate \$\mathhat{R}_{sp}\$ is given by Coit [2] as .
To estimate the variance of the reliability estimate, reference [2] uses the estimates to replace the true, but unknown values for \$q_{ij}\$ and \${\rm var}(\mathhat{r}_{ij})\$ in (28).
In the next section, two examples are presented to demonstrate the proposed method, and the results are compared to the data given by [1], [2].
The data were originally presented in [2].
The model previously proposed by Coit [2] is BSBC.

links.abstract: A flexible procedure is described and demonstrated to determine approximate confidence intervals for system reliability when there is uncertainty regarding component reliability information. The approach is robust, and applies to many system-design configurations and component time-to-failure distributions, resulting in few restrictions for the use of these confidence intervals. The methods do not require any parametric assumptions for component reliability or time-to-failure, and allows type-I ...

references.text: D. W. Coit, "System reliability confidence intervals for complex systems with estimated component reliability", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 46, no. 4, pp. 487-493, 1997.

references.title:
Variance of system reliability estimates with arbitrarily
repeated components

context.text: Jin & Coit [3] extended this variance decomposition to systems that have arbitrarily repeated components.

links.abstract: A model is developed to determine the variance of system reliability estimates and to estimate confidence intervals for series-parallel systems with arbitrarily repeated components. For these systems, different copies of the same component-type are used several or many times within the system, but only a single reliability estimate is available for each distinct component-type. The single estimate is used everywhere the component appears in the system design, and component estimation-error is th...

references.text: T. Jin, D. W. Coit, "Variance of system reliability estimates with arbitrarily repeated components", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 50, no. 4, pp. 409-413, 2001.

references.title: On the exact variance of product

context.text: Goodman [4] derived a general formula for estimating the exact variance of the product of two random variables.

references.text: L. Goodman, "On the exact variance of product", Journal of American Statistical Association, vol. 50, no. 292, pp. 708-713, 1960.

references.title:
Confidence bounds for the reliability of binary capacitated
two-terminal networks

context.text: Ramirez-Marquez & Jiang [5] further developed confidence bounds on the reliability of capacitated networks; and more recently, Ramirez-Marquez & Levitin [6] applied a universal generating function (UFG) approach for the estimation of system reliability, and its associated confidence bounds.

references.text: J. E. Ramirez-Marquez, W. Jiang, "Confidence bounds for the reliability of binary capacitated two-terminal networks", Reliability Engineering & System Safety, vol. 91, no. 8, pp. 905-914, 2006.

references.title:
Algorithm for estimating reliability confidence
bounds of multi-state system

context.text: Ramirez-Marquez & Jiang [5] further developed confidence bounds on the reliability of capacitated networks; and more recently, Ramirez-Marquez & Levitin [6] applied a universal generating function (UFG) approach for the estimation of system reliability, and its associated confidence bounds.

references.text: J. E. Ramirez-Marquez, G. Levitin, "Algorithm for estimating reliability confidence bounds of multi-state system", Reliability Engineering & System Safety, 2008.

references.title:
Approximate confidence limits for system
reliability

context.text: Easterling [7], and Rosenblatt [8] used variance decomposition methods to approximate the variance of the system reliability estimate as a linear combination of variances of component reliability estimates based on the Taylor series expansion.

references.text: R. G. Easterling, "Approximate confidence limits for system reliability", Journal of the American Statistical Association, vol. 67, no. 337, pp. 220-222, 1972.

references.title: Confidence limits for reliability of complex systems

context.text: Easterling [7], and Rosenblatt [8] used variance decomposition methods to approximate the variance of the system reliability estimate as a linear combination of variances of component reliability estimates based on the Taylor series expansion.

references.text: J. Rosenblatt, "Confidence limits for reliability of complex systems" in Statistical Theory of Reliability, 1963, Madison, University of Wisconsin Press.

references.title: Non-parametric estimation from incomplete observation

context.text: The reliability data in Table I are binomial testing data, but time-to-failure data with type-I and type-II censoring can be analyzed in a similar way using Kaplan-Meier non-parametric statistics [9].

references.text: E. L. Kaplan, P. Meier, "Non-parametric estimation from incomplete observation", Journal of American Statistical Association, vol. 53, pp. 457-481, 1958.

references.title:
An analytical method for uncertainty analysis
of nonlinear output function, with application to fault-tree analysis

context.text: Cox [10] used conditional expectation to partition the variance of the system reliability estimate among contributing causes using orthogonal decomposition.

links.abstract: An analytic method for uncertainty analysis of the output of a complex model is described. It is assumed that model inputs are s-independent random variables and that model output is given as an analytic though possibly nonlinear function of the inputs. Using conditional s-expectations as a tool, a theoretical basis is developed for a method of partitioning the variance of the output among contributing causes. Such a partitioning helps the system analyst to identify the most important contributo...

references.text: D. W. Cox, "An analytical method for uncertainty analysis of nonlinear output function with application to fault-tree analysis", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-3, no. 5, 1982.

references.title:
A robust measure of uncertainty importance
for use in fault tree system analysis

context.text: Iman & Hora [11], and McKay [12] analyzed the sensitivity problem based on the decomposition of the variance of a system performance index.

references.text: R. L. Iman, S. C. Hora, "A robust measure of uncertainty importance for use in fault tree system analysis", Risk Analysis, vol. 10, no. 3, pp. 401-406, 1990.

references.title:
Nonparametric variance-based methods of

context.text: Iman & Hora [11], and McKay [12] analyzed the sensitivity problem based on the decomposition of the variance of a system performance index.

references.text: M. D. McKay, "Nonparametric variance-based methods of assessing uncertainty importance", Reliability Engineering and System Safety, vol. 57, no. 3, pp. 267-279, 1997.

references.title: A sensitivity analysis for importance analysis

context.text: The works of Saltelli [13], Sobol' [14], and Alis & Rabitz [15] further established the theoretical background for the utilization of variance-based techniques.

references.text: A. Saltelli, "A sensitivity analysis for importance analysis", Risk Analysis, vol. 2, no. 3, pp. 579, 2002.

references.title: A new uncertainty measure

context.text: Recently, Borgonov [16] made a comprehensive comparison between variance-based sensitivity measures with a moment-independent uncertainty indictor.

references.text: E. Borgonov, "A new uncertainty measure", Reliability Engineering and System Safety, vol. 92, pp. 771-784, 2007.
